source: # Big Data Final Project
## 1. Download Target Dataset and Preparation

In the first part, the data of interest (oral parliamentary questions submitted to the UK parliament) is retreived via the UK Parliament's API. Because I am interested in the gender and party affiliation of each MP who asked a question, more information about them is scraped from the UK Parliament website and merged with the other dataset.

#import all necessary packages for part 1
import requests
import json
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd 
from os import path
from pandas.io.json import json_normalize #import module to flatten nested list
import random
random.seed(1983) #reproducible results
np.random.seed(1983)

#import data via API access
startDate = "2013-04-01"
endDate = "2021-04-15" 
size=44726 #all data available from this website (older data is in old archives)
base = "https://lda.data.parliament.uk/commonsoralquestions/answerDate.json?"
url = f"{base}startDate={startDate}&endDate={endDate}&_pageSize={size}"
data = requests.get(url)

type(items) #items is a list.
print(len(items)) #could not download full data set but only 10,000 items at a time, download 10,000 items more

#this is quite tedious, and there might be an easier way to do this
startDate = "2013-04-01"
endDate = "2020-07-05" 
size=10000
base1 = "https://lda.data.parliament.uk/commonsoralquestions/answerDate.json?"
url = f"{base1}startDate={startDate}&endDate={endDate}&_pageSize={size}"
data1 = requests.get(url)
data1 = data1.json()

len(data1)
result_acc = data1["result"]
items1 = result_acc["items"]
len(items1)

#third page (this could probably be done with a for loop...)
startDate = "2013-04-01"
endDate = "2018-09-10" 
size=10000
base2 = "https://lda.data.parliament.uk/commonsoralquestions/answerDate.json?"
url = f"{base1}startDate={startDate}&endDate={endDate}&_pageSize={size}"
data2 = requests.get(url)
data2 = data2.json()
len(data2)
result_acc = data2["result"]
items2 = result_acc["items"]
len(items2)
#fourth page
startDate = "2013-04-01"
endDate = "2016-06-14" 
size=10000
base3 = "https://lda.data.parliament.uk/commonsoralquestions/answerDate.json?"
url = f"{base1}startDate={startDate}&endDate={endDate}&_pageSize={size}"
data3 = requests.get(url)
data3 = data3.json()
len(data3)
result_acc = data3["result"]
items3 = result_acc["items"]
len(items3)
#fifth page
startDate = "2013-04-01"
endDate = "2014-03-19" 
size=10000
base4 = "https://lda.data.parliament.uk/commonsoralquestions/answerDate.json?"
url = f"{base1}startDate={startDate}&endDate={endDate}&_pageSize={size}"
data4 = requests.get(url)
data4 = data4.json()
len(data4)
result_acc = data4["result"]
items4 = result_acc["items"]

#flatten all five dictionaries after extraction
df = pd.json_normalize(items) 
df1 = pd.json_normalize(items1) 
df2 = pd.json_normalize(items2) 
df3 = pd.json_normalize(items3) 
df4 = pd.json_normalize(items4) 
#merge 40,000 items into one dataframe
dfm = pd.concat([df, df1, df2, df3, df4], ignore_index=True)

#create .csv with scraped data 
compression_opts = dict(method='zip', archive_name='parlquest2013-2021.csv')  
df.to_csv('parlquest2013-2021.csv', index=False, compression=compression_opts)
len(dfm) #has 43,103 items

### 1.1 Get Party and Member of each MP in dataframe

#Get party and gender via API of the UK parliament
base = "https://lda.data.parliament.uk/members.json?" #download dataset with party information and gender 
url = f"{base}_pageSize={size}"
member = requests.get(url)
member = member.json()
size=5000
mem = member["result"]
memb = mem["items"]
len(memb)
memberdf = pd.json_normalize(memb) #normalize to dataset
memberdf.head()
memberdf = memberdf.rename({'_about': 'tablingMember._about'}, axis=1)  # new method

## 2. Train Classifier on Manifesto Project Data (Keras + Tensorflow DL)

### 2.1 Download Source Corpus

Get data from manifest project via API (downloaded from mp website using R, as it is more efficient). using R I downloaded all items in English that are annotated.
Code for extraction with R: https://github.com/ambercloe/bidatafinproject/blob/main/ManifestoDataCorpusForTrainingAllEnglish.R
Personal API Key required, and can be downloaded as a .txt file after signing up to https://manifesto-project.wzb.eu

### 2.3 Train and Evaluate Keras Tensorflow Model 
Several parts in the following are copied and modified from Github-user @codehax41 1https://github.com/codehax41/BBC-Text-Classification/blob/master/BBC%20using%20Keras.ipynb
Where copied, the cell is marked with @codehax41
#split dataset into train, test and val and shuffle set ()
train_texts, test_texts, train_labels, test_labels = train_test_split(texts, labels, test_size=.2, stratify=labels, shuffle=True) #split and shuffle dataset with sklearn package

#import packages for building and training classifier 
max_words = 8000 #model training with more input could not be perfomed on local CPU
layers = keras.layers #define layers
models = keras.models 
#create tokenizer
tokenize = keras.preprocessing.text.Tokenizer(num_words=max_words, 
                                              char_level=False)

# Converts the labels to a one-hot representation (code by @codehax41: https://github.com/codehax41/BBC-Text-Classification/blob/master/BBC%20using%20Keras.ipynb)
tokenize.fit_on_texts(train_texts) # fit tokenizer to our training text data
x_train = tokenize.texts_to_matrix(train_texts) 
x_test = tokenize.texts_to_matrix(test_texts)

# convert label strings to numbered index @codehax 41
encoder = LabelEncoder()
encoder.fit(train_labels)
y_train = encoder.transform(train_labels)
y_test = encoder.transform(test_labels)
# Converts labels to a one-hot representation
num_classes = np.max(y_train) + 1
y_train = keras.utils.to_categorical(y_train, num_classes)
y_test = keras.utils.to_categorical(y_test, num_classes)

#Parts of code copied and modified from Github-user @codehax41 (see: https://github.com/codehax41/BBC-Text-Classification/blob/master/BBC%20using%20Keras.ipynb). 
# set hyperparamaters for data (and tweaking around with it!). 
epochs = 4 #how many times algorithm works through layers
drop_ratio = 0.5 #to prevent overfitting, introduces noise (typically 0.5-08)
batch_size = 32 #larger batch size leads
# build sequential model 
model = models.Sequential()
model.add(layers.Dense(512, input_shape=(max_words,)))
model.add(layers.Activation('relu'))
model.add(layers.Dense(num_classes))
model.add(layers.Activation('softmax')) #converts vector to vector of probabilities
model.compile(loss='categorical_crossentropy',
              optimizer='adam',
              metrics=['acc']) #instead of metrics= [acc] => accuracy

#fit model on training dataset 
history = model.fit(x_train, y_train,
                    batch_size=batch_size,
                    epochs=epochs,
                    verbose=1,
                    validation_split=0.1, shuffle=True) #set what percentage of data should be used for validation data (20%)

#Code copied and modified from Github-user @codehax41 (see: https://github.com/codehax41/BBC-Text-Classification/blob/master/BBC%20using%20Keras.ipynb). 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.style.use('ggplot')

def plot_history(history): #define function to plot learning history plot
    acc = history.history['acc']
    val_acc = history.history['val_acc']
    loss = history.history['loss']
    val_loss = history.history['val_loss']
    x = range(1, len(acc) + 1)

    plt.figure(figsize=(12, 5))
    plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
    plt.plot(x, acc, 'b', label='Training acc')
    plt.plot(x, val_acc, 'r', label='Validation acc')
    plt.title('Training and validation accuracy')
    plt.legend()
    plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)
    plt.plot(x, loss, 'b', label='Training loss')
    plt.plot(x, val_loss, 'r', label='Validation loss')
    plt.title('Training and validation loss')
    plt.legend()
plot_history(history)

#define confusion matrix  #define confusion matrix 
def plot_confusion_matrix(cm, classes,
                          title='Confusion matrix',
                          cmap=plt.cm.Blues):
    """
    This function prints and plots the confusion matrix.
    Normalization can be applied by setting `normalize=True`.
    """

    cm = cm.astype('float') / cm.sum(axis=1)[:, np.newaxis]

    plt.imshow(cm, interpolation='nearest', cmap=cmap)
    plt.title(title, fontsize=30)
    plt.colorbar()
    tick_marks = np.arange(len(classes))
    plt.xticks(tick_marks, classes, rotation=45, fontsize=22)
    plt.yticks(tick_marks, classes, fontsize=22)

    fmt = '.2f'
    thresh = cm.max() / 2.
    for i, j in itertools.product(range(cm.shape[0]), range(cm.shape[1])):
        plt.text(j, i, format(cm[i, j], fmt),
                 horizontalalignment="center",
                 color="white" if cm[i, j] > thresh else "black")

    plt.ylabel('True label', fontsize=25)
    plt.xlabel('Predicted label', fontsize=25)

#summarize parties to either Conservative, Labour or Others, and drop na
membt = membt.dropna(axis=0, subset=['party._value'])
parties ={'Alba Party':'Other','Alliance':'Other','Conservative':'Conservative','Democratic Unionist Party':'Other','Green Party':'Other','Independent':'Other','Labour':'Labour','Labour (Co-op)':'Labour','Liberal Democrat':'Other','Plaid Cymru':'Other','Scottish National Party':'Other','Social Democratic & Labour Party':'Other','The Independent Group for Change':'Other','UK Independence Party':'Other','Ulster Unionist Party':'Other', 'Con':'Conservative', 'Other':'Other'}
membt['Party']= membt['party._value'].apply(lambda x : parties[x])
pd.crosstab(index=membt['Domain'], columns=membt['Party'], margins=True, margins_name="Overall", normalize='columns')\
    .round(4)*100

#Crosstab Political Domains by Gender
pd.crosstab(index=membt['Domain'], columns=membt['Gender'], margins=True, margins_name="Overall", normalize='columns')\
    .round(4)*100

###Visualize
#Code coped and modified from https://github.com/Slothfulwave612/soccerplots/blob/master/docs/radar_chart.md
# There might be an easier way to do this but with the amount of data it seems fine. 
# part 1
## parameter names

params = ['Economy','Environment, Culture & Equality','External Relations', 'Social Fabric & Groups', 'Political System, Democracy & Freedom', 
          'Welfare']
## range values
rangem = [(0.0, 40.0), (0.0, 40.0), (0.0, 40.0), (0.0, 40.0), (0.0, 40.0), (0.0, 40.0)]

## parameter value
values = [
    [30.17,13.46,4.46,16.47,8.95,26.49],   ##Female
    [30.11,13.34,4.34,17.35,9.43,25.43]    ## Male 
]

title = dict(
    title_name='Women MPs',
    title_color='#B6282F',
    subtitle_color='#B6282F',
    title_name_2='Men MPs',
    title_color_2='#344D94',
    subtitle_color_2='#344D94',
    title_fontsize=18,
    subtitle_fontsize=15,)
## endnote 
endnote = "Code from Github(@slothfulwave612)"
## instantiate object 
radar = Radar()
## plot radar -- alphas
fig, ax = radar.plot_radar(ranges=rangem, alphas=[0.5, 0.5], params=params, values=values, compare=True, radar_color=['#B6282F', '#344D94'], title=title, endnote=endnote)
